items.title: Parents urge province to create standard of care for Ontario students with diabetes
items.summary_auto: Parents whose children have Type 1 diabetes are urging the Ministry of Education to create a provincewide standard of care for diabetes in schools, so it doesn't vary from classroom to classroom, school to school, or board to board.

items.title: Carney heading to Munich for world's top security conference
items.summary_auto: Prime Minister Mark Carney is heading to Germany later this week for the world's top security conference, as Canada works to update its own defence policy.

items.title: Canadian lugers Allan, Podulsky to make history in Olympic debut of women's doubles
items.summary_auto: Calgarians Kailey Allan saw Beattie Podulsky will be the first women representing Canada in women's doubles luge, making its Olympic debut at the Cortina Sliding Centre in Italy.

items.title: Sask. man fights off starving moose with fists, shovel and bullets to save his mother
items.summary_auto: A starving and cold moose was huddled against the house, tucked next to the warmth of a dryer vent. It didn’t take long before it attacked Angie Tuffnell.

items.title: Canada’s military ombudsman flags decade-long failure to fix reservist compensation system
items.summary_auto: Canada's military ombudsman has released a new report that provides a reality check on the Defence Department's plans to increase the size of the reserve force. Mario Baril's report takes the federal government to task for ignoring major problems with the primary reserve, where soldiers lack adequate health care and are often left out of pocket.

items.title: Inquiry into troubled Winnipeg police HQ project begins Tuesday with witness testimony
items.summary_auto: Hearings in the long-awaited inquiry into the procurement and construction of Winnipeg’s police headquarters are scheduled to start Tuesday, with testimony from city officials who were involved in the troubled project.

items.title: Ukrainian trains with helmet honouring fellow athletes killed in war. IOC says it's banned for race
items.summary_auto: Ukrainian Vladyslav Heraskevych will not be allowed to wear a "helmet of remembrance" in honour of ​those killed in the war with Russia in the skeleton competition at the Winter Games, the International Olympic Committee said on Tuesday. Not long afterward, Heraskevych wore the tribute helmet for his first of two training runs on Tuesday, which suggests that Ukraine has filed an appeal.

items.title: Chappell Roan leaves Casey Wasserman talent agency over Epstein emails
items.summary_auto: New files related to late financier and ​sex offender Jeffrey Epstein published by the U.S. Justice Department last month, included flirtatious email ⁠exchanges between Wasserman and ‍Ghislaine Maxwell dating from ⁠2003.

items.title: The buzz of Milano-Cortina? Olympic drones offer dizzying perspectives
items.summary_auto: Drones that allow for high speeds following athletes' every twist and turn offer a new perspective on Olympic play at the Milano-Cortina Winter Games.

items.title: After 5 die in house fire, First Nation chief seeks more firefighting support as man's murder sentence looms
items.summary_auto: Nearly seven years after a woman and four children died in a house fire in northwestern Ontario, sentencing looms for a man found guilty of second-degree murder, while the chief of Kitchenuhmaykoosib Inninuwug (KI) calls for adequate firefighting services to prevent future tragedies.

items.title: Video game Relooted tasks you with reclaiming African artifacts in museums
items.summary_auto: Relooted, a new video game from African-based studio Nyamakop, tasks players with stealing real-life African artifacts from museums and private mansions to return them to their rightful historical owners.

items.title: Why some Canadians are betting big on 3D printed housing in Canada
items.summary_auto: Linda Reisman invested almost $700,000 in a robotic arm that can 3D print concrete walls. Her plan is to print her own home, but she also believes the technology can help solve Canada's housing crisis. While a few developers have embraced 3D printing to produce a handful of housing projects across the country, some experts say only time will tell if the technique will catch on.

items.title: Ontario declines Hamilton residents' request to investigate ArcelorMittal Dofasco emissions
items.summary_auto: Some residents say Canada’s largest steelmaker is “emitting dangerous pollutants” at levels far above Ontario’s local air-quality regulation and violating sections of the Environmental Protection Act.

items.title: Ottawa commits $84M to install more than 8,000 EV chargers
items.summary_auto: In an effort to address range anxiety and get more drivers into electric vehicles, the federal government is committing to fund and further expand the country's EV charging infrastructure.

items.title: Canada discreetly puts money down on 14 additional F-35s
items.summary_auto: Ottawa has started to make payments for key components for 14 additional U.S.-built F-35s, even as the Carney government has been reviewing future fighter-jet purchases in the context of trade tensions with Washington, sources have told CBC News.

items.title: Toronto city council to debate budget that Chow says prioritizes affordability
items.summary_auto: The proposed budget features a 2.2 per cent property tax increase and more than $1 billion funding increases for the TTC and Toronto police.

items.title: I thought I understood what animal testing meant until I brought home a former lab dog
items.summary_auto: When Nives Ilic adopted a six-year-old dog that had been used for animal research, she was apprehensive that bringing home an animal with behavioural challenges would upend her life. But Mack surprised her with his gentleness, and made her realize what was at stake.

items.title: Next chapter in bitter Canada-U.S. women's hockey rivalry begins Tuesday
items.summary_auto: The preliminary round game between the cross-border rivals begins at 2:10 p.m. ET on CBC and CBC Gem. Both teams will advance to the quarterfinals no matter the result.

items.title: Blood pressure drug recalled after mix-up: Health Canada
items.summary_auto: A blood pressure medication has been recalled after a mix-up that may have led to some bottles containing the wrong drug. According to Health Canada, Marcan Pharmaceuticals Inc. has recalled two lots of MAR-Amlodipine 5 milligram tablets, which are used to treat high blood pressure and chest pain.

items.title: Food allergies can be triggered in infancy, a new review says. Here's how
items.summary_auto: A new review of studies gives families and doctors a better understanding of what drives food allergies in babies and children.

items.title: Trump threats on Gordie Howe bridge opening 'just insane,' Windsor mayor says
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump's threat to stall the opening of the new Canada- U.S. border crossing is "just insane," Windsor Mayor Drew Dilkens said Monday night.

items.title: Trump threatens to block opening of new bridge between Windsor and Detroit
‘If you’re reading this I’m dead, and I really liked you,’ professor writes in posthumous postcards
items.summary_auto: Don Glickman didn't want a funeral, or even an obituary. Instead, the retired U.S. design professor opted for something more straightforward — postcards, delivered posthumously to his friends and favourite students, with the simple message: “If you’re reading this I’m dead, and I really liked you."

items.title: Liberal MP Bruce Fanjoy criticizes government's latest return-to-office order
items.summary_auto: Bruce Fanjoy, the Liberal MP for Carleton, has broken ranks with his party to criticize the federal  government's latest return-to-office (RTO) mandate.

items.title: Guthrie family at 'hour of desperation' in search for their missing mother
items.summary_auto: Savannah Guthrie's family is "at an hour of desperation" in the search for her missing mother, the Today show co-host said in a video released Monday ahead of a looming ransom deadline apparently set by Nancy Guthrie's abductors.

items.title: B.C. premier says 2,000 public service jobs cut and counting as province faces $11.2B deficit
items.summary_auto: Premier David Eby says public service jobs that don’t support the front-line delivery of services to British Columbians will continue to be targeted as his government prepares to unveil its 2026 budget a week from now.

items.title: Canada beats Czechia, but captain Poulin exits game with apparent injury
items.summary_auto: Canadian captain Marie-Philip Poulin left the first period of an Olympic women's hockey game against Czechia with an apparent knee injury and did not return for the second.

items.title: Catherine O'Hara died of blood clot in lung, says L.A. Medical Examiner's Office
items.summary_auto: Actor Catherine O'Hara died of a blood clot in her lung, according to the Los Angeles Medical Examiner's Office.

items.title: Fact check: Are Russia and Belarus in the Olympics?
items.summary_auto: Twenty athletes with Russian and Belarusian passports are competing in the Winter Olympics, but they’re not representing a country. Here are the facts about 'Individual Neutral Athletes.'

items.title: 'Operational pressure' sparks Via Rail cancellations in Toronto, Ottawa, Montreal
items.summary_auto: Via Rail says recent train cancellations within its Toronto-Ottawa-Montreal corridor are being made in response to "heightened operational pressure."

items.title: Experiencing menopause symptoms? Here's what experts say can help
items.summary_auto: With menopause symptoms ranging from sleep trouble to burning mouth syndrome, people aren't always sure what they're experiencing. The Dose spoke to clinicians and researchers at the forefront of menopause care in Canada about the latest treatments, from hormone therapy to exercise and diet.

items.title: B.C. Greens pull out of cooperation agreement with B.C. NDP
items.summary_auto: The Greens, which have two seats in B.C.’s legislature, will not sign a new co-operation agreement with the NDP government, saying the party has stalled or sidelined too many of the measures it agreed to.

items.title: Ancient people had nautical tech, know-how to cross hazardous Arctic channel
items.summary_auto: Archeologists have found the remains of a cluster of tents with hearths on a remote High Arctic island that date back more than 4,000 years. They offer surprising new insights about the first people who lived near what is now the Canada-Greenland border.

items.title: Trial begins for Sask. group home worker charged with assaulting residents
items.summary_auto: Jaclyn Elias, 38, was fired from the Prairie Branches group home after the allegations arose two years ago in the small community of Wilkie, Sask.
